They have been operating as Robin Hood in reverse.Â  Stealing from the poor to reward their rich cronies. . . . I think what you have here is a case study on the proponents of the Clinton wing of the Democratic Party, and they tend to be left-leaning, how these people got together and figured out a charity where foreigners can give unlimited amounts of money, and U.S. players can give unlimited amounts of tax deductible money to an entity.Â  This could be a preferred vehicle for strengthening the Clinton wing of the Democratic Party and Clinton interests around the world.â€ Even though the Clinton Foundation is an official charity with a so-called â€œ501(c) 3â€ designation from the IRS, Ortel says itâ€™s not functioning as a legitimate charity. Ortel charges on his website that â€œClinton Foundation documents omit crucial facts, include false and materially misleading statements, and exclude legally required audits of financial statements for each year of operation, that must be prepared on a consistent basis.â€ Ortel also explains, â€œThere are two sides to the coin. I think Peter Schweizer (Clinton Cash author) and his team have done a very good job of exposing this very difficult to expose pay-to-play stuff.Â  I doubt there are criminals dumb enough who sit down and write memoranda in great detail and say â€˜alright, you give me $1 million and Iâ€™ll give your this ambassadorship. Â Â Letâ€™s sign on the dotted line here.Â  Please wire the money to this account.â€™Â  I donâ€™t think you are going to find those types of records.Â  At the end of the day, even if you write a great book, and the book is good, and even if you do a movie and the movie is good, at the end of the day, the skeptical press is going to say there is no evidence.â€ Ortel goes on to say, â€œOn the other hand, on charity fraud, itâ€™s a very different thing. In charity fraud, unlike pay-to-play, you donâ€™t have to prove intent.Â  Under New York State law, in particular, the requirement is merely that you prove the public filings in the Clinton Foundation are false and materially misleading, and they certainly are. This is why you are starting to see these editorial boards around the world say wait a minute.Â  You also have to prove that they solicited, not that they raised money, that they solicited.Â  That, the Clintons have admitted. . . . On the charity fraud side of life, that is the mine field for the Clintons.Â  The second the IRS, or any attorney general or a state taxing authority, decides to make an issue of this, the burden of proof shifts . . . Â the charity has to come forward and prove the affirmative case.Â  The Clinton Foundation has to prove, since October 23, 1997, that all you have been doing exclusively is furthering the authorized tax exempted purposes, which as far as I know is, to be merely a research facility and archive based in Little Rock.Â  Prove thatâ€™s all you have done.Â  Show us the legally audited financial statements.Â  Show us those audits.â€ In closing, Ortel contends, â€œThis is a tale that needs to be told, but itâ€™s not going to be a tale that people swallow at first blush given the fact how powerful the Clintons are or how vengeful the Clintons are when they are in power. . . .
